abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Kerala Water Supply and Sanitation
            project in India. The specific Project objectives were to:
            (a) assist in strengthening the operational and financial
            roles of Kerala Water Authority (KWA), by promoting manpower
            development and operational efficiency; (b) provide piped
            water supplies to about one million people residing in seven
            rural areas; (c) increase the supply of water and extend the
            distribution facilities in one urban area to about 150,000
            people; and (d) introduce low-cost on-site sanitation Low
            Cost Sanitation (LCS) facilities and finance their
            construction so as to benefit about 200,000 people residing
            in ten urban areas and to undertake a similar pilot program
            for low-cost sanitation in rural areas. Bank’s performance
            was not satisfactory. Borrower’s performance was less
            satisfactory. The key lessons learned were: (i) many of the
            problems of implementation which beset this project could
            have been foreseen and arose from poor identification and
            preparation; (ii) the single most important conclusion to
            emerge from the project management experience, therefore, is
            that greater effort both by Bank and borrower needs to go
            into these early stages of the project cycle; (iii)
            appraisal should occur only when the project is truly ready;
            and (iv) a subsidiary conclusion for similar projects in the
            future in India and elsewhere is that field level
            supervision effort by the Bank needs to be substantial
            during the early stages of implementation to ensure that the
            Project remains firmly on the rails.
